speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: SCENE III. The same. A street.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Thunder and lightning. Enter from opposite sides, CASCA, with his sword drawn, and CICERO

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Good even, Casca: brought you Caesar home?

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Why are you breathless? and why stare you so?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Are not you moved, when all the sway of earth

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Shakes like a thing unfirm? O Cicero,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: I have seen tempests, when the scolding winds

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Have rived the knotty oaks, and I have seen

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: The ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: To be exalted with the threatening clouds:

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: But never till to-night, never till now,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Did I go through a tempest dropping fire.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Either there is a civil strife in heaven,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Or else the world, too saucy with the gods,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Incenses them to send destruction.

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Why, saw you any thing more wonderful?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: A common slave--you know him well by sight--

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Held up his left hand, which did flame and burn

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Like twenty torches join'd, and yet his hand,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Not sensible of fire, remain'd unscorch'd.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Besides--I ha' not since put up my sword--

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Against the Capitol I met a lion,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Who glared upon me, and went surly by,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Without annoying me: and there were drawn

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Upon a heap a hundred ghastly women,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Transformed with their fear; who swore they saw

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Men all in fire walk up and down the streets.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: And yesterday the bird of night did sit

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Even at noon-day upon the market-place,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Hooting and shrieking. When these prodigies

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Do so conjointly meet, let not men say

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: 'These are their reasons; they are natural;'

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: For, I believe, they are portentous things

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Unto the climate that they point upon.

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Indeed, it is a strange-disposed time:

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: But men may construe things after their fashion,

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Clean from the purpose of the things themselves.

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Come Caesar to the Capitol to-morrow?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: He doth; for he did bid Antonius

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Send word to you he would be there to-morrow.

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Good night then, Casca: this disturbed sky

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Is not to walk in.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Farewell, Cicero.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Exit CICERO

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Enter CASSIUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Who's there?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: A Roman.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Casca, by your voice.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Your ear is good. Cassius, what night is this!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A very pleasing night to honest men.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Who ever knew the heavens menace so?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Those that have known the earth so full of faults.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For my part, I have walk'd about the streets,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Submitting me unto the perilous night,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And, thus unbraced, Casca, as you see,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Have bared my bosom to the thunder-stone;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And when the cross blue lightning seem'd to open

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The breast of heaven, I did present myself

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Even in the aim and very flash of it.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: But wherefore did you so much tempt the heavens?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: It is the part of men to fear and tremble,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: When the most mighty gods by tokens send

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Such dreadful heralds to astonish us.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You are dull, Casca, and those sparks of life

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That should be in a Roman you do want,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Or else you use not. You look pale and gaze

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And put on fear and cast yourself in wonder,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To see the strange impatience of the heavens:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But if you would consider the true cause

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Why all these fires, why all these gliding ghosts,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Why birds and beasts from quality and kind,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Why old men fool and children calculate,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Why all these things change from their ordinance

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Their natures and preformed faculties

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To monstrous quality,--why, you shall find

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That heaven hath infused them with these spirits,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To make them instruments of fear and warning

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Unto some monstrous state.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Now could I, Casca, name to thee a man

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Most like this dreadful night,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That thunders, lightens, opens graves, and roars

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: As doth the lion in the Capitol,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A man no mightier than thyself or me

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In personal action, yet prodigious grown

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And fearful, as these strange eruptions are.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: 'Tis Caesar that you mean; is it not, Cassius?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Let it be who it is: for Romans now

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But, woe the while! our fathers' minds are dead,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And we are govern'd with our mothers' spirits;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Indeed, they say the senators tomorrow

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Mean to establish Caesar as a king;

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: And he shall wear his crown by sea and land,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: In every place, save here in Italy.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I know where I will wear this dagger then;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Cassius from bondage will deliver Cassius:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Therein, ye gods, you make the weak most strong;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Therein, ye gods, you tyrants do defeat:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Nor stony tower, nor walls of beaten brass,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Nor airless dungeon, nor strong links of iron,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Can be retentive to the strength of spirit;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But life, being weary of these worldly bars,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Never lacks power to dismiss itself.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If I know this, know all the world besides,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That part of tyranny that I do bear

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I can shake off at pleasure.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Thunder still

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: So can I:

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: So every bondman in his own hand bears

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: The power to cancel his captivity.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And why should Caesar be a tyrant then?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Poor man! I know he would not be a wolf,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But that he sees the Romans are but sheep:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: He were no lion, were not Romans hinds.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Those that with haste will make a mighty fire

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Begin it with weak straws: what trash is Rome,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: What rubbish and what offal, when it serves

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For the base matter to illuminate

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: So vile a thing as Caesar! But, O grief,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Where hast thou led me? I perhaps speak this

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Before a willing bondman; then I know

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: My answer must be made. But I am arm'd,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And dangers are to me indifferent.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: You speak to Casca, and to such a man

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: That is no fleering tell-tale. Hold, my hand:

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Be factious for redress of all these griefs,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: And I will set this foot of mine as far

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: As who goes farthest.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: There's a bargain made.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Now know you, Casca, I have moved already

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To undergo with me an enterprise

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Of honourable-dangerous consequence;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And I do know, by this, they stay for me

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In Pompey's porch: for now, this fearful night,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: There is no stir or walking in the streets;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And the complexion of the element

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In favour's like the work we have in hand,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Most bloody, fiery, and most terrible.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Stand close awhile, for here comes one in haste.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: 'Tis Cinna; I do know him by his gait;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: He is a friend.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Enter CINNA

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Cinna, where haste you so?

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: To find out you. Who's that? Metellus Cimber?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: No, it is Casca; one incorporate

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To our attempts. Am I not stay'd for, Cinna?

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: I am glad on 't. What a fearful night is this!

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: There's two or three of us have seen strange sights.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Am I not stay'd for? tell me.

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: Yes, you are.

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: O Cassius, if you could

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: But win the noble Brutus to our party--

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Be you content: good Cinna, take this paper,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And look you lay it in the praetor's chair,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Where Brutus may but find it; and throw this

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In at his window; set this up with wax

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Upon old Brutus' statue: all this done,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Repair to Pompey's porch, where you shall find us.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Is Decius Brutus and Trebonius there?

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: All but Metellus Cimber; and he's gone

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: To seek you at your house. Well, I will hie,

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: And so bestow these papers as you bade me.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That done, repair to Pompey's theatre.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Exit CINNA

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Come, Casca, you and I will yet ere day

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: See Brutus at his house: three parts of him

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Is ours already, and the man entire

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Upon the next encounter yields him ours.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: O, he sits high in all the people's hearts:

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: And that which would appear offence in us,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: His countenance, like richest alchemy,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Will change to virtue and to worthiness.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Him and his worth and our great need of him

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You have right well conceited. Let us go,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For it is after midnight; and ere day

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: We will awake him and be sure of him.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Exeunt
